problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

constants.description: List of items to place in the box

decision_variables.description: Number of boxes used to pack all items, minimized as objective
Assignment of each item to a box with box id
X and Y positions of each item within its assigned box

constraints:
# -- Constraints --


# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def items_fit_exactly_in_assigned_boxes(
    items: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item),
    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    box_width: int,
    box_height: int
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        # Ensure item fits within the dimensions of the assigned box
        assert assignments[i].x + items[i].width <= box_width
        assert assignments[i].y + items[i].height <= box_height

items_fit_exactly_in_assigned_boxes(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, BOX_WIDTH, BOX_HEIGHT)

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def no_overlap_constraints(
    items: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item),
    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    box_width: int,
    box_height: int
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Only check overlap if both items are in the same box
            if assignments[i].box_id == assignments[j].box_id:
                # Check if rectangles (items) overlap
                # Not overlapping conditions (at least one separating line exists)
                assert (
                    assignments[i].x + items[i].width <= assignments[j].x or
                    assignments[j].x + items[j].width <= assignments[i].x or
                    assignments[i].y + items[i].height <= assignments[j].y or
                    assignments[j].y + items[j].height <= assignments[i].y
                )

no_overlap_constraints(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, BOX_WIDTH, BOX_HEIGHT)

# --- constraints ---
def ensure_item_box_assignment_validity(
    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment)
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        # Ensure each item is assigned to exactly one box (implicitly ensured by variable definition)
        # Box IDs are constrained via BoxAssignment.box_id definition
        assert assignments[i].box_id >= 1
        assert assignments[i].box_id <= 10
        # Positional constraints are inherently satisfied due to domain limits in BoxAssignment

ensure_item_box_assignment_validity(item_box_assignments)
full_formulation:
# --- Objects ---


Item = DSRecord({
    "width": DSInt(lb=1, ub=8),
    "height": DSInt(lb=1, ub=17)
})

BoxAssignment = DSRecord({
    "box_id": DSInt(lb=1, ub=10),
    "x": DSInt(lb=0, ub=8),
    "y": DSInt(lb=0, ub=17)
})



# --- Constants and Decision Variables ---
BOX_HEIGHT: int = 17
BOX_WIDTH: int = 8
ITEMS: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item) = [
    {"width": 8, "height": 13},
    {"width": 4, "height": 6},
    {"width": 2, "height": 10},
    {"width": 6, "height": 11},
    {"width": 3, "height": 16},
    {"width": 1, "height": 16},
    {"width": 2, "height": 14},
    {"width": 4, "height": 5},
    {"width": 3, "height": 8},
    {"width": 1, "height": 2}
]
N_ITEMS: int = 10
nr_used_boxes: DSInt(lb=1, ub=10)
item_box_assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment)
x_y_positions: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment)
N_ITEMS : int = 10
N_ITEM_BOX_ASSIGNMENTS : int = 10
N_X_Y_POSITIONS : int = 10


# --- objective ---
def calculate_objective(assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment)) -> DSInt(lb=1, ub=10):
    max_box_id: int = 0
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        if assignments[i].box_id > max_box_id:
            max_box_id = assignments[i].box_id
    return max_box_id

objective = calculate_objective(item_box_assignments)
nr_used_boxes = objective
minimize(objective)

# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---

        assert assignments[i].y + items[i].height <= box_height

                assert (

                    assignments[j].x + items[j].width <= assignments[i].x or
                    assignments[i].y + items[i].height <= assignments[j].y or
                    assignments[j].y + items[j].height <= assignments[i].y
                )

no_overlap_constraints(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, BOX_WIDTH, BOX_HEIGHT)

# --- constraints ---
def ensure_item_box_assignment_validity(
    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment)

constraints:
# -- Constraints --


# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def items_fit_exactly_in_box(
    items: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item),
    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    box_width: int,
    box_height: int
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        item_width: int = items[i].width
        item_height: int = items[i].height
        pos_x: int = assignments[i].x
        pos_y: int = assignments[i].y
        assert pos_x + item_width <= box_width
        assert pos_y + item_height <= box_height

items_fit_exactly_in_box(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, BOX_WIDTH, BOX_HEIGHT)

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def no_overlap(
    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    items: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item)
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Only check overlap if both items are in the same box
            if assignments[i].box_id == assignments[j].box_id:
                # Extract values directly to avoid temporary variables
                xi: int = assignments[i].x
                yi: int = assignments[i].y
                wi: int = items[i].width
                hi: int = items[i].height
                xj: int = assignments[j].x
                yj: int = assignments[j].y
                wj: int = items[j].width
                hj: int = items[j].height
                # Check that rectangles do not overlap
                assert xi + wi <= xj or xj + wj <= xi or yi + hi <= yj or yj + hj <= yi

no_overlap(item_box_assignments, ITEMS)

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def ensure_item_in_one_box_only(
    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment)
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        box_id: int = assignments[i].box_id
        assert box_id >= 1
        assert box_id <= 10

ensure_item_in_one_box_only(item_box_assignments)

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

constants.initialization: ITEMS : Annotated[list[Item], Len(10, 10)] = [ITEM1, ITEM2, ITEM3, ITEM4, ITEM5, ITEM6, ITEM7, ITEM8, ITEM9, ITEM10]

decision_variables.description: Number of boxes used in the end to pack all all items. Minimizing it is the objective.
Which item is assigned to which box.
Position x and y of each item within box

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---

def items_fit_exactly_in_boxes(
    items: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item),
    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    positions: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment)
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        # Ensure item fits within the box dimensions
        assert positions[i].x + items[i].width <= BOX_WIDTH
        assert positions[i].y + items[i].height <= BOX_HEIGHT
        # Link box assignments with positions
        assert assignments[i].box_id == positions[i].box_id
        assert assignments[i].x == positions[i].x
        assert assignments[i].y == positions[i].y

items_fit_exactly_in_boxes(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, x_y_positions)

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def no_overlap_constraints(
    items: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item),
    positions: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment)
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Check if items i and j are in the same box
            same_box: bool = positions[i].box_id == positions[j].box_id
            if same_box:
                # Check if rectangles overlap
                overlap_x: bool = positions[i].x < positions[j].x + items[j].width and positions[j].x < positions[i].x + items[i].width
                overlap_y: bool = positions[i].y < positions[j].y + items[j].height and positions[j].y < positions[i].y + items[i].height
                # If items are in the same box, they must not overlap
                assert not (overlap_x and overlap_y)

no_overlap_constraints(ITEMS, x_y_positions)

        assert assignments[i].box_id >= 1
        assert assignments[i].box_id <= 10

ensure_item_in_one_box_only(item_box_assignments)

constraints:
# -- Constraints --


# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def items_fit_exactly_in_boxes(
    items: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item),
    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    box_width: int,
    box_height: int
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        item_width: int = items[i].width
        item_height: int = items[i].height
        pos_x: int = assignments[i].x
        pos_y: int = assignments[i].y
        assert pos_x + item_width <= box_width
        assert pos_y + item_height <= box_height

items_fit_exactly_in_boxes(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, BOX_WIDTH, BOX_HEIGHT)

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def no_overlap_constraints(
    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    items: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item),
    box_width: int,
    box_height: int
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Only check overlap if both items are in the same box
            if assignments[i].box_id == assignments[j].box_id:
                # Get item dimensions
                w_i: int = items[i].width
                h_i: int = items[i].height
                x_i: int = assignments[i].x
                y_i: int = assignments[i].y
                
                w_j: int = items[j].width
                h_j: int = items[j].height
                x_j: int = assignments[j].x
                y_j: int = assignments[j].y
                
                # No overlap condition: at least one of the following must be true
                # Item i is to the left of item j
                # Item i is to the right of item j
                # Item i is above item j
                # Item i is below item j

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Assignment of each item to a box
X and Y positions of each item within their assigned box

def calculate_objective(assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment)) -> DSInt(lb=1, ub=10):
    max_box_id: int = 0
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        if assignments[i].box_id > max_box_id:
            max_box_id = assignments[i].box_id
    return max_box_id

):

        item_width: int = items[i].width
        item_height: int = items[i].height

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.

def no_overlap(
    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    items: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item)
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Only check overlap if both items are in the same box
            if assignments[i].box_id == assignments[j].box_id:
                # Extract values directly for use in constraints
                x1: int = assignments[i].x
                y1: int = assignments[i].y
                w1: int = items[i].width
                h1: int = items[i].height
                
                x2: int = assignments[j].x
                y2: int = assignments[j].y
                w2: int = items[j].width
                h2: int = items[j].height

                # Assert that rectangles do not overlap
                assert (x1 + w1 <= x2) or (x2 + w2 <= x1) or (y1 + h1 <= y2) or (y2 + h2 <= y1)

no_overlap(item_box_assignments, ITEMS)

each_item_in_exactly_one_box(item_box_assignments)

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

constants.description: List of items with their dimensions

decision_variables.description: Number of boxes used to pack all items, minimized as objective
Assignment of each item to a box with box id and position
X and Y positions of each item within its assigned box
